intro: Ophrys mattinatae, commonly known as the Alpina Orchid, is a rare and specialized orchid species native to the alpine regions of southern Europe. It is characterized by its unique, intricate flower structure that closely resembles a female bee, a feature that plays a crucial role in its pollination strategy. The plant typically grows in rocky or sandy soils at high altitudes, where it thrives in cool, moist conditions. Its flowers are usually pale green or yellowish with dark markings, and it blooms between May and July. Due to habitat loss and climate change, Ophrys mattinatae is considered a vulnerable species requiring conservation efforts.
